entry.title: How SAP’s ABAP Cloud Partner Reference App Simplifies Multi-Tenant Side-by-Side Extensions on BTP
entry.content:
The SAP BTP ABAP environment continues to unlock powerful opportunities for partners and developers seeking to extend and integrate with SAP Cloud ERP - particularly SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, by enabling SaaS extension development, leveraging existing ABAP expertise, and delivering benefits such as harmonized user experience, built-in product standard compliance, and simplified lifecycle management and operations out of the box. To further support this process, SAP offers the open-source ABAP Partner Reference Application as a best-practice resource.

The ABAP Partner Reference Application on SAP-Samples Git repository demonstrates how to design, build, and operate multi-tenant side-by-side applications using ABAP Cloud practices while following SAP’s recommended development approaches. The ABAP Partner Reference Application provides developers and technical architects with standard patterns, modular code, and documented guidance for building robust, multi-tenant ABAP applications on SAP BTP, fully integrated with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. It guides partners on designing, deploying, and extending ABAP solutions. It provides a blueprint for building scalable, multi-tenant apps that extend and integrate with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

 

What is the ABAP Partner Reference Application?

The ABAP Partner Reference Application (APRA) is a sample implementation that provides practical examples, such as the Music Festival Manager. It shows partners how to:

  • Build extensions on SAP BTP ABAP Cloud.
  • Integrate seamlessly with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.
  • Handle critical multi-tenant aspects such as tenant provisioning, onboarding, and isolation.
  • Follow SAP’s ABAP Cloud and Restful ABAP Programming Model (RAP) guidelines.

In short, it’s a real-world blueprint for partners who need a reference starting point.

Key Capabilities Highlighted

  • Multi-tenancy design: APRA showcases how to build applications that serve multiple tenants securely while keeping data isolated.
  • Tenant lifecycle management: Includes practical examples of provisioning and onboarding processes.
  • Integration patterns: Demonstrates how ABAP applications can consume SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition APIs side by side, extending core business logic without modification.
  • Best practices in ABAP Cloud: Clean-core extensions, RAP-based services, and modular design patterns are applied throughout

Why It Matters for Partners

For partners building SAP-certified solutions, alignment with ABAP Cloud principles is no longer optional. APRA offers more than just example code: it provides implementation guidance to ensure solutions are cloud-ready, scalable, and compliant. By studying and adapting the repository, partners save time, reduce uncertainty, and can fast-track their certification and deployment processes.

  • The repository demonstrates and aligns with SAP clean-core architecture and RAP best practices, enabling maintainable, upgrade-safe solutions. Along with modularization, helping partners build solutions that are scalable, maintainable, and compliant with SAP’s cloud-first best practices.
  • It provides real-world samples for rapid development of side-by-side extensions in the SAP BTP ABAP environment.
  • It demonstrates end-to-end flows: business object modelling, onboarding and provisioning, secure multi-tenancy, and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition API integration. It includes example business objects, tenant-specific onboarding logic, and detailed sample integrations with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition APIs, serving as ready-to-adapt templates for real-world enterprise scenarios.
  • Each step—from tenant lifecycle management to extending SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition functionality using side-by-side applications—is implemented with guidance notes and sample ABAP artifacts, making cloud development approachable for teams at any skill level.
  • Multi-Tenancy Patterns: Learn how to isolate data and processes by tenant, automate provisioning, and secure user access using SAP BTP role collections and dedicated onboarding flows.
  • Integration Points: Discover how to consume core APIs, events, and data from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition while preserving ERP clean core, using recommended SAP BTP services for authentication, navigation, and extensibility.
  • RAP and ABAP Cloud Usage: Access sample RAP service definitions and back-end logic that illustrate SAP’s latest cloud-based application paradigms, making it straightforward to adopt modern development models.

 Getting Started / How to Use the Repository

The repository is publicly available on GitHub and welcomes exploration. Developers can:

  • Import the Music Festival Manager application from your abapGit repository into your ABAP environment in ADT, browse the artifacts, and review the README for instructions on deployment and configuration to start with ready-to-run examples or tutorials.
  • Follow the incremental development guides in the main branch to build up your own ABAP partner app using the same best practices. Follow examples for multi-tenant design, onboarding, and integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.
  • Analyze business object definitions, RAP service implementations, and onboarding/integration logic to adapt for your own solution. Use the sample reference application as templates for partner apps, adapting the RAP artifacts and onboarding logic for your business scenario and leverage the documented guidance to use APRA as a starting template for your own solutions.

Inside the Repository: Packages and Artifacts

  • The repository is organized to guide developers through building a core ABAP application, then evolving it into a multi-tenant solution.
  • Artifacts are grouped by application logic (business objects), onboarding flows, integration APIs, and service definitions that illustrate SAP’s recommended RAP approach.
  • The samples Music Festival Manager and Poetry Slam Manager demonstrate business object modeling, UI integration, and tenant isolation in real-world use cases.

 How the Repository Accelerates Partner Solutions

  • Partners can reuse packages, study onboarding approaches, and adapt integration modules directly for their own certified offerings—streamlining time to market and improving solution quality.
  • Step-by-step documentation, real code, and sample data flows empower developers to master multi-tenant patterns and extend SAP Cloud systems with confidence.
  • The repository acts as a knowledge base and starter kit for enterprise ABAP cloud projects, bridging theory and practical implementation for SAP’s partner ecosystem.

By exploring this repository, developers and architects gain hands-on experience with the foundations of multi-tenant architecture, SAP BTP-managed security, and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition integration—directly addressing the needs of modern cloud-native SAP applications.

For partners, the repository turns cloud-native theory into practice. Get hands on with SAP BTP ABAP Cloud, accelerate certified solution development, and leverage proven patterns for multi-tenant extensions—all with guided help from SAP’s own reference implementation.

entry.title: Switching to Spaces and Pages Experience Sharing – Changing Page Tile Colors on My Home Page
entry.content:
Introduction

It has been a while since I touched the topic of Spaces and Pages in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Today I am going to continue my series on Spaces and Pages – Changing Page Tile Colors.

Recently one user raised a question:  In the News and Pages section of My Home page, those page tiles were colorful. However, after the 2508 upgrade, they became mono color.  I am going to explain what happened and the steps to bring back the colors and transport this UI change to the Test and Production tenants in a 3 System Landscape.

 

Background

The user sees two different sets of Page Tiles below, one is the mono color after 2508 Upgrade, and another one is the colorful tiles before upgrade in the Starter System which you usually don’t upgrade.

 Mono Color Page Tiles on a 2508 System

 Colorful Tiles on a Starter System (Prior to 2508 Release)

When we talk about these Page Tile colors, a few things need to keep in mind:

  • When a system is delivered or upgraded, the original color is set by the developers. The original color could be gray as shown above if nobody changes it.
  • System administrator can change the colors of these Page Tiles. This color change impacts to all users.  Individual users cannot change the Page Tile color.
  • The color change is part of Key User UI Adaptation effort.

In the next section, I am going to detail the steps to change the Page Tile colors.

 

Steps to Change Page Tile Color

Below figure is my News and Pages section in the Dev tenant.  There are six Page Tiles, only one tile “Customers and Products” has a default gray color.  The remaining five tiles are all colorful.

Six Page Tiles in News and Pages Section

 To Change the title color, we will take the Key User UI Adaptation route.  You can see some explanations in SAP Help Portal, Adapting the UI.

You go to the User Action Menu, select Adapt UI.  Click on the OK button when you see an Info message pop-up: “You have personalized the app or there are public views.  The app is reloading without these changes”.  It might take a few more seconds until you see the below figure which has “UI Adaptation – Navigation – Visualization” in the Title Bar. 

Note 1: At current 2508 release, the UI Adaptation Tool is still not 100% compatible with the Fiori Launchpad. So, you might have to click on “Adapt UI” user menu for the 2nd time to enter the UI Adaptation Tool. This situation will improve in a later release.

Note 2: The pop-up message means for My Home page, there are already changes made by users. The system is going to bring up the app with different versions.

Note 3: The Version History is working, but not robust yet. If you switch to an old version, try to refresh the screen  in your web browser to bring the setting from the server to the frontend. I will talk about it  more later.

Now you click on the right mouse button, the pop-up button Personalize My Home shows up.

UI Adaptation Mode

 Clicking on Personalize My Home button, My Home Settings window pops up. Then expand News and Pages menu in My Home Settings window. Now Edit News and Pages window pops up.

My Home Settings Window

 Expanding the Spaces and Pages menu, you get the Edit Pages window. Here you can scroll up and down in the left panel titled Spaces and Pages to find the page tile you are interested in. For example, I find the Space Internal Sales, Page Sales Processing. By selecting this page, I can change its tile color to one of 10 available colors shown on the right hand side.

Change the Color of a Page Tile

 You might notice that Internal Sales Overview Page Tile has a green color in My Home page, but it shows the gray color on the list. That’s because the developers changed the tile color before its release, the original color (not the default color) is green. The gray color in the list indicates it is still the original color, not touched by the Key User; it could be red or green; or even gray like Page Customers and Products, since the developers leave the default color there as the original color.

After you select the color, click the Close button in the Edit Pages window.  Then click the Save button in the My Home Settings button.

When you come back to the UI Adaptation window, you notice the Sales Processing tile has changed the color.  Also, there is a Draft text in the Version History area.  By expanding the Version History, you can see the entire history of this UI Adaptation.  My current version is still in Draft state, Unpublished. 

Draft State of UI Adaptation

 If you cannot make the final decision on your change, you can save your Draft by clicking the Save button on the right-hand side in the title bar. Keep in mind that other Key Users can edit your draft version change as well. It creates an opportunity to the team work.

Next step of changing the color of a tile is to Activate it by clicking on the button to the right.

The Activation Button of the UI Adaptation Tool

A new window Activate New Version pops up. Try to give a meaningful title and easy for you to find it later in the Version History. I enter “Change color of Sales Processing tile”.  Then, hit the Confirm button.

Give a Name to the New Version

 Now the Version History text changed from “Draft” to “Change color of Sales Processing tile” in green and a Truck icon appears. A new version is born.  You use the Truck icon to publish this UI Adaptation so that all end users can use it.  In addition, you can export this UI Adaptation to your Test and Production tenants.

The Publish Button of the UI Adaptation Tool

After the publication, hit the X button on the right of the UI Adaptation Tool Bar to exit from the tool. Then another pop-up window shows.  It basically tells you that the screen will be refreshed to load your latest version.

Info Pop-Up Window “App Requires Reload”

 

Switch Back to Old Color

Sometimes we need to reverse our work, for example, some end users don’t like the changes we made. This is possible.

To do this, you select an older version from the Version History dropdown list. Refresh the screen to see exactly what old color is! Otherwise, you still see the latest version.  In my example, I selected the very original version called "Original App". Now the Page Tile Sales Processing is changed back to its original color of gray.

Bring back the Original Color

 A little different from our normal understanding, we need to create a new version based on the old version, not just reactivate an old version. Only the version at the top of the Version History can be active, and you cannot move up an old version to the top.  So, when you click on the Activate New Version button, a Reactivate Version window pops up.

Enter Text for Reactivate Version

 Check the Version History, a new version Reverse to Original App is there.  I still need to publish it so that all end users can use it.

The Version History Dropdown List

 

Transport Your Change to the Test and Production Tenants

I have written a blog on Transport Your Spaces and Pages Configurations in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud 3-System Landscape Systems.  It explains all the details of creating and delivering a transport.

After I create a new Software Collection called Page Tile Adaptation, I need to add content to it by clicking the Add Item button. 

Software Collection Page Tile Adaptation

 When you search which content to be added to your UI Adaptation Export Collection, use the filter Type “UI Flexibility: Views and Changes (UIFLEX_CD)”, you should be able to find your content.

Set Filter Type as “UI Flexibility: Views and Changes (UIFLEX_CD)”

 If you make several changes to this Page Tile as I did in this blog, i.e., assigning a color, then reverse it back to the original color, there is only one content item S/4HANA Product Home.

Add an UI Adaptation Content to an Export Software Collection

 After adding the content to the Software Collection, I click on the Inventory button to find out what’s inside.

Add Content Item S/4HANA Product Home to the Software Collection Page Tile Adaptation

The Inventory button opens a Change History of the Content Item S/4HANA Product Home.  Within two days of writing this blog, I made changes four times until assigning this collection to the Software Collection Page Tile Adaptation.

List of All Changes Made to the Content Item S/4HANA Product Home

 

Conclusion

As an administrator, you can change the color of the Page Tiles in My Home page for all users by using the Key User UI Adaptation tool.  You can bring the colorful page tiles back to your My Home page.

 

References

  • Transport Your Spaces and Pages Configurations in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud 3-System Landscape Systems
  • Switching to Spaces and Pages Experience Sharing – My Three Best Practices of Using Spaces and Pages
  • Switching to Spaces and Pages Experience Sharing - Deploying Spaces and Pages Best Practices
  • Switching to Spaces and Pages Experience Sharing - Assigning Predefined S&P to Your Own Biz Roles
  • Switching to Spaces and Pages Experience Sharing - Using Display Security Audit Log Fiori App

entry.title: Test Data Conversion, the accelerator: scaling smart
entry.content:
In our Data Migration for Test Environment Validation in ... - SAP Community Blog, we explored Test Data Conversion (TDC) and Test Data Refresh (TDR), the potential pathways for test system readiness as part of the 3 SL post-conversion activity. We have also seen the unique value added by both the services. If you're seeking deeper insight into Test Data Conversion (TDC), you're in the right place. In this blog we will see a comprehensive overview of TDC, purpose, and value added by TDC.  

Customer satisfaction is the cornerstone of any business. To ensure a seamless transition into 3 SL conversion, TDC is being offered as a one-time complimentary service to all the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 3 SL conversion customers by SAP. 

Before we delve into the full scope and benefits of TDC, Let’s have an understanding on the key prerequisites for TDC implementation. 

TDC Pre-requisites: 

To ensure a seamless and efficient data transfer during the TDC enablement process, below key prerequisites must be fulfilled at the system level: 

  1. Uniform Software Release Across all tenants: 
    • All Tenants must operate on the same software release configuration. 
    • This consistency helps eliminate system discrepancies and ensures reliable data flow. 
  2. System Configuration Maintenance 
    • A well-maintained System configuration is essential for seamless TDC execution. 
    • It supports system stability there by reduces integration friction.  
  3. Content Version Alignment 
    • All tenants should be in the same content version release. 
    • Version mismatches can lead to errors during data transfer and could lead to incomplete data mapping.  
  4. Extension Readiness 
    • Ensure all relevant extensions are active and configured with the latest updates. 
    • The Handle Your Extensions app will come handy to verify and manage extensions efficiently. 
  5. Clean Development Transport Queue 
    • Confirm that there are no open transports in the development queue. 
    • The transport queue should be clean to avoid data inconsistency or conflicts. 

Note:  if you need help with the first three prerequisites, The conversion team will help you to validate and maintain the necessary configurations across tenants. This simplifies the process and ensures readiness for TDC onboarding. 

TDC: Enabling Seamless Data Transition for tenant post-conversion 

The TDC service offers a powerful solution for transferring reliable data from the development tenant to the test tenant. It supports the migration of: 

  • Master Data 
  • Transactional Data 
  • Historical Test Data 
  • System Configurations (e.g., Output Management and others) 

 By this, TDC will not only take care of data, but also help in setting up certain configurations thereby reduces manual setup efforts and accelerate system readiness process. One of the critical components in system setup is the Output Management Configuration. TDC streamlines this process by automatically transferring output management configuration data from the development tenant to the new test tenant. In addition to configuration data, TDC also migrates all available test automation assets, ensuring that testing frameworks and scripts are ready to resume at the earliest. 

One of the key concerns during data migration is data privacy. TDC service offers depersonalization as an optional feature, which ensures sensitive information (Workforce data is out of scope) is anonymized during the transfer process. 

Note: Depersonalization is a broad and critical topic. While this blog focuses on understanding TDC, reference links will be provided below for those who wish to explore depersonalization in detail. 

Once the data migration via TDC is complete, the system reaches a near-ready state, as a next step initiate Rewiring of Applications as a Post migration step to ensure the alignment of applications with the new test tenant. This step ensures seamless integration with applications and functionality across the system landscape. 

Note: Rewiring of apps is beyond the scope of this blog. Kindly refer to SAP help page for those who wish to explore Rewiring of apps in more detail. 

With consistent and complete data in place and successful rewiring of apps, the test tenant becomes fully operational. This marks the transition of test tenant from setup to active usage. All available test automation scripts from the development tenant can now be resumed. This helps to validate system integrity, confirm readiness, and ensure smooth performance post conversion. 

Conclusion: 

In this Blog, we’ve explored the pre-requisite, scope of TDC. We've also seen how TDC significantly reducing manual effort and saving time during the 3 SL post conversion process. 

We hope this has provided you with a comprehensive and clear understanding of TDC, its benefits, and its role in enabling a smoother transition to the new Test tenant.

Definition :  The Custom Analytical Queries app is a tool used for reporting and analysis.

This tool transforms and organizes raw data delivered from business documents into a meaningful grid. It abstracts the process of writing structured queries so that you don’t have to understand the query language or the technical details.

Custom Analytical Queries provides the fields required to design a query. You select the required fields and set filters for your query. You can add restricted measures, calculated measures, and preview the query results. The various options in Custom Analytical Queries and the task that you can perform using the options are as follows:

  • Search: Use to search an existing query.

  • New: Use to create a query.

  • Copy: Use to create queries from predefined SAP queries or from packages that you do not have permissions.

  • Adding Dimensions and Measures from the Data Source: Use to add a field from a data source to define a query or to remove a field from the query.

( Definition referred From :  Custom Analytical Queries - SAP Doc )

In my words , Custom analytical queries are a tool for dynamic representation of data in rows and columns which provide meaningful insights , business intelligence and summarization of data in a higher to lower drilldown model with aggregations and segregations .

( Literally I'm too bad in defining things in my own words )

You can consider the Custom analytical queries as a Key User extensible approach , but there are few scenarios where we might need the support of Developer extensions to meet our requirements .  Which will be explained below in the following portions . 

where to find the custom analytical queries ? 

Once you are in your Public cloud Launchpad , use the search bar  .

Or use the Left hamburger menu and scroll down till you find the Analytics  Section .

Once you click the Analytics  Section , You can find the Tile under the Query Design part .

How to Create an Analytical Query ? 

Navigate inside the tile , you can see the list of existing custom analytical queries and the  create button  .

SAP has already provided us some  analytical queries and all the released queries will be available here , we can use the existing ones as well as create our own . 

Now click on the create button and following pop up will come .

You can give your Analytical query name and choose the Data source you need and click on OK . 

click on the Data Source search help and you can see all your available data sources .

 

 after choosing the data source of you need you can continue with the field selection , setting the Dimensions ,setting  Measures , setting the filters , calculations etc ...

Before moving to the next segment or part of adjusting and setting query for our use , let me give you an idea about the data sources used in the Analytical queries or what are these data sources ? 

The data sources shown here are of 3 types mainly : 

1. SAP created and Released Analytical Queries and Cube

2. Custom Analytical Cube created using the Custom CDS view APP .

  

3. Custom CDS views Created Using Developer extensibility and the C1 contract set for Use in key user apps . There are few other things to be careful as well , you can use the sample code added below for reference .

Now lets Fall back to our scenario , I am creating an Analytical query with the name Analytical_Q2 and data source  I_ACCOUNTINGDOCUMENTJOURNAL , one of SAP released / Standard CDS views.

and you will be on the next screen after clicking OK .

You will be in the first tab General , 

in the General tab under properties , you can :

  • add your Label 
  •  Name and Data source will be displayed 
  • Set the Zero suppression

Under the Additional Properties , you can :

  •  Processing effort for the query , Low / Medium / High 
  • Set Run Time extensibility 

On the top right corner you can see your status of the Query (Draft / Saved / published )

On the bottom right you can see buttons for , Saving Draft / Publishing / Previewing 

 

Moving to the Next Tab  Field selection : 

You can see all your fields available in the Data source here . Check the selection check box for fields you will be needing in the query . 

After selecting the check box you can see that most of the fields fell in to the Free axis position but some of them have automatically fallen to the Measure category . Mostly the fields with amount , quantity or marked as measure in the data source fall to this category. 

If you look closely to the field list , you can see the type of field . 

  • if a field is having  symbol , this is a dimension and could be placed in the ROW / Column axis of the report / Query.
  • if a field is having  symbol , this is a measure and could be placed in the COLUMN axis of the report / Query.
  • if a field is having  symbol , this is a date field and could be placed in ROW / Column axis of the report / Query.

In data analysis, dimensions are qualitative, descriptive fields (like names, dates, or categories) that provide context and "slice" data, answering "who," "what," "when," and "where". Measures are quantitative, numerical fields (like sales, quantities, or profits) that you calculate or aggregate to answer "how much" or "how many". The core difference is that dimensions provide the descriptive context, while measures provide the numerical values to analyze within that context. 

Dimensions
Purpose: To provide context, segment, and describe data.
Data Type: Qualitative, categorical, or descriptive data.
Examples:
Product names, customer IDs, region, date.
Information like "who," "what," "where," and "when".
Measures
Purpose: To be calculated and aggregated, such as sums or averages, to provide quantifiable insights. 
Data Type: Quantitative, numerical, and measurable data. 
Examples: 
Sales, profit, quantity, price, and temperature. 
Information that answers "how much" or "how many". 
 
Moving to the Next Tab Display :
Now you can move the fields to your desired axis , Row / Column. To do that you can either select the field and use the up , down button in the table to move the fields and place it in order . Or you can also use the Axis field in the options area and place the field in different Axis.
I have adjusted the axis in the following order: 
Now lets focus the main table with fields from left ,
  • you will see Remove column with x button to remove the field from the selection.
  • Filter column to set the Filed as a filter ( We will look at the Filter in the next section or tab).
  • Display column to hide / show the field in output. 
  • Name , label and Type as seen earlier and also a row wise hierarchy  separator to show the fields category or placement.
 
Now lets Save our Query and have a Preview :
We will consider this preview for comparing with changes we are going to next.
Now lets select a field in the row category and look at the available properties (Right Pane) . 

 

  • Use the Override Label to change the default Label :
  • Display option to set field visible .
  • Display result Option to enable Total / Grand total row based on this field .
  • Dimension format to display either the Key  / text / Key and text / text and Key  value of the Field , Applicable in case of fields with Key and value pair , eg : Country , currency , company code etc 
  • Sorting to set the sorting for the Field , Ascending / descending . 
  • Axis is to place the field at desired axis (Row / Column).
  • Include Unbooked data option to show values with this field as empty but others having data .
 
Now lets look at a Measure and its Properties :
  • Use the Override Label to change the default Label :
  • Display option to set field visible .
  • Decimals option to define the number of decimal places needed.
  • Scaling option to set the level of scaling .
  • Reverse sign to reverse the sign of value .
  • Use  the hierarchy  Part to set the Hierarchy of the field if needed.
  • Collapsed to set the view to collapsed .
  • Enable hierarchy to enable hierarchy , Collapsed will only work if hierarchy is set . 
  • Parent option to set the parent node of the current field in the hierarchy.
 
Now after making some changes let me show the preview again :
Moving to the Next Tab Filters :
 
Here lets select a Row / Dimension and set the Filter values , Only dimensions are allowed as filters .
 
  • You can set No filter for a field , which will be default .
  • Fixed Filter with values to
    • include and exclude.
  • User Input Values Filter with
    • selection type  Single / Interval
    • Multiple selection
    • Mandatory Option
    • Variable sequence
    • Default value
  • Derivation Functions with 
    • Lookup entity (Search help )
    • Hidden 
    • Mandatory

Now after making some changes let me show the preview again :

 

Now we have covered almost all the options in all the tabs , but we haven't explored the ADD button in the Display tab . 

This option lets you add :

  • Add Restricted Measure
  • Add Calculated Measure
  • Add Converted Measure
  • Add Counter
  • Add User Input Filter
  • Add Characteristic Structure Element
     
     
     
    I have also skipped the publishing process and adding the custom analytical query as a tile in this tile , I will try to write all the missing parts in the part 2 blog 😁 .

entry.title: Introducing Our New Customer Influence Request Template for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
We’re pleased to share a refreshed version of our customer request template—now aligned with SAP's new product operating model. Starting September 29th 2025, you will see this new template in action.

What’s New?

The new template shifts the focus from feature requests to problem-solving and business outcomes. It’s designed to help you clearly describe your challenges, propose solutions, and highlight the value of improvements—so our product teams can respond faster and more effectively.

Why This Matters

This new format helps us:

  • Understand your real-world challenges more clearly
  • Deliver solutions that matter—not just features
  • Strengthen our collaboration with you to build innovative products with high usage and customer satisfaction

Before You Get Started

  1. A thorough business description from your end is much appreciated.
    This will reduce the need for follow-up questions and minimize back-and-forth communication.
  2. Any request details underpinning your submission are valuable, as they provide us with the overarching context of your business needs.

Here’s what the new structure looks like:

REQUEST DESCRIPTION

  1. Describe the problem, issue or challenge you are facing within the overall business process.
  2. Propose a solution to address the identified problem, issue or challenge.
  3. Explain how you as a company or the impacted business role will benefit from this improvement.

REQUEST DETAILS

To help us process your request efficiently, please provide the following information:

  • Business Role
  • SAP Fiori App ID 

    ​Reference: For the SAP Fiori app ID or the business role affected, reference official qualifiers from the SAP Fiori Apps Reference Library.

  • Component Name (application component hierarchy, if you cannot specify an SAP Fiori App ID)
  • Scope Item
  • Attachments: Upload a screenshot or relevant file via the Attachments tab.

SAP BUSINESS SUITE INTEGRATION:
Relevant only if your request covers integration to other public Cloud products

Does this request support the use of SAP Business Suite, consisting of multiple SAP public cloud products*, in a more user friendly, more integrated or more extensible way? If yes, state how.

* Examples include: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central, SAP ConcurExpense, SAP Sales Cloud Version 2, etc.

You will see this change applied in most Customer Influence sessions for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. It isn’t just about formatting; it’s about making your voice more actionable and impactful in how we build and improve SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. We believe it will make it easier for you to share what matters most—and for us to act on it.

Thank you for your continuous feedback to improve SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and the SAP Business Suite.
